head.title: Is It Time for a Higher Gas Tax?

hedline.hl1: Is It Time for a Higher Gas Tax?

block.p: The 18.4-cents-a-gallon federal gasoline tax (24.4 cents for diesel) is widely understood to be a ''user fee'' that finances the Highway Trust Fund. Motorists and truckers who pay these taxes at the pump trust that their contributions will lead to better and safer roads.
Your proposal to raise fuel taxes for new nonhighway purposes is a nonstarter. That policy would be regressive and unlikely to achieve the goals you set out.

The 18.4-cents-a-gallon federal gasoline tax (24.4 cents for diesel) is widely understood to be a ''user fee'' that finances the Highway Trust Fund. Motorists and truckers who pay these taxes at the pump trust that their contributions will lead to better and safer roads.
Your proposal to raise fuel taxes for new nonhighway purposes is a nonstarter. That policy would be regressive and unlikely to achieve the goals you set out.

Artificially manipulating the price of energy in this way would have an insignificant effect on oil dependency. Gasoline at $3 or $4 a gallon could not come close to reducing our oil imports from the level of 58 percent now to even the 1973 level of 28 percent.

Only a combination of increased domestic oil production and advanced research into finding alternatives that can truly compete in the market with oil offers any promise of achieving energy independence.
In regard to climate change, we have found a less painful solution to reduce carbon dioxide emissions: traffic congestion relief.
Gregory M. Cohen President and Chief Executive American Highway Users Alliance Washington, Oct. 24, 2005
